content:
- 20 -
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
CONSULTANT SERVICES AND TRAINING FACILITIES
Maximal effectiveness in the work of the International Centres obviously requires not only a network of National Centres throughout the world but also that these National Centres should have the skilled and competent staffing to which reference has been made in the paragraph immediately above. A National Centre with an enthusiastic but unskilled staff may be even more of a hindrance to the smooth and efficient operation of the scheme as a whole than one that is merely inactive, since the enthusiastic but unskilled Centre would tend to flood the International Centre with routine or irrelevant material and so to throw too much of a strain on the latter's resources of time, materials and manpower.
While it is, then, essential that the National Centres should be staffed by experts in his highly specialized work, there are still very few countries in which such personnel is available. It is suggested that one means of improving the status and quality of enteric bacteriological work in a country's public health services would be by arranging for visits of a reasonable length of time by senior staff members of the more developed National Centres to other countries in order to advise on the functioning of National Centres of this type. 許躍爾
140.112.213:82
As for training facilities, these are already available at all three Centres. At Atlanta systematic courses, under the general heading of "Laboratory Diagnosis of Bacterial Diseases, Enteric Bacteriology (8.50)", lasting 10 to 12 days, are offered annually to a class of about 20 students. A more advanced course entitled "Special problems in Enteric Bacteriology (8.51)", is also available, by special arrangement, for a minimum period of two weeks for classes limited to two or three students. The Copenhagen and London Centres do not teach organized groups but prefer to take individual trainees by arrangement. The WHO Fellowships Programme could perhaps make a useful contribution towards the wider exploitation of these facilities. 1
1 Fellowships are granted by WHO on application by national health administrations on behalf of candidates of their own selection, and not on application by candidates themselves direct to WHO. An information booklet entitled "WHO Fellowships", available at the offices of all national health administrations, gives fuller details of the purposes of the Fellowships and of the conditions under which they are awarded.
國史饭 Academia Historica
92 :selected:

Maximal effectiveness in the work of the International Centres obviously requires not only a network of National Centres throughout the world but also that these National Centres should have the skilled and competent staffing to which reference has been made in the paragraph immediately above. While it is, then, essential that the National Centres should be staffed by experts in his highly specialized work, there are still very few countries in which such personnel is available.
